utterances: All right.
There was a U.S.

State Department narcotics report this year that described what it says is pervasive public corruption in the government of Jamaica as well as at Kingston's ports that facilitated the movement of drugs and money through Jamaica.
Quote: ""Corruption remains a major barrier to improving counter-narcotics efforts."" Is that description of Jamaica accurate, do you think?
I think it's a little bit exaggerated.
I would not doubt that there may be a few people within the administration who are involved.
And I think that's one of the reason why the Americans are so intent on getting Mr. Coke.
I don't think it's widespread within the government, and certainly government and certainly not, it's not, it's not, it's not coming from the top of the government as well.
All right.
Let's get Andrew on the line.
Andrew with us from Fort Atkinson in Wisconsin.
Good afternoon, gentlemen.
I actually just came back from Kingston on Thursday morning.
And I have one actual question, very important question for your guest.

What a lot of people, regardless of their party, are talking about is this is the end of Bruce Golding, current prime minister's political career, because of how badly the whole situation was botched at that level.
Yes.
Yeah, I think it's going to be very difficult for him to bounce back from this.
He's been politically wounded.
The whole affair, starting from last August when he - when it became clear that he was resisting this extradition, and then the recent revelation that he sanctioned this approach through the U.S.
law firm Manatt, Phelps & Phillips to lobby on behalf of the fellow - of Mr. Coke.
Surprisingly, there are some people in the know who have told us that he's actually just taking the blame because he didn't -he got a lot of the information after the fact.

Really and truly, that says quite a bit about his leadership, because if you have people inside your organization who are doing these things without clearing them with you first, it suggests that you don't have your hands firmly on the reins as you should.
I think he's very, very wounded.
I can't see the ruling party going back into an election with him as their leader.
I think he's going to have to make some succession - some organization - some planning for succession and step down soon.
Andrew, thanks very much for the call.
Appreciate it.
Thank you.
And Vernon Davidson, we thank you for your time.
And of course our condolences on the tremendous loss of life there in Kingston and hopes that this can be resolved peacefully.
Thank you very much, sir.
Vernon Davidson, executive editor of publication for the Jamaica Observer, with us today on the line from his office in Kingston, Jamaica.
This is WEEKEND EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Rachel Martin.
Put down your eggs benedict and Mother's Day mimosa because it is time for the puzzle.
(SOUNDBITE OF THEME MUSIC)
Joining me now is WEEKEND EDITION's puzzle-master Will Shortz.
Good morning, Will.
Morning, Rachel.
Happy Mother's Day.
Thank you very much.
And how's that Mother's Day mimosa going?
Yeah, right.
I wish.
Later, after the show, my Mother's Day mimosa.
So, refresh our memories, Will.
What was last week's challenge?
Yes.
I asked you to name a famous performer whose last name has six letters.
Move the first three letters to the end without otherwise changing the order of the letters, and add one more letter at the end.
The result, in seven letters, will name a place where this person famously performed.
Who is it, and what's the place?
Well, the person was Callas, as in Maria Callas.
And you do that operation and you get La Scala.
OK.
About 680 listeners had it right this week.
And our randomly selected winner is Dena Sanford of Harrison, Nebraska.
She is on the line now.
Hi, Dena.
Hi, there.
Congratulations.
Thank you.
So, are you a big opera fan?
How did you figure this out?
(LAUGHTER)
I never listen to opera.
How did this come to you?
Just by chance?
Oh, utterly, yes.
My husband actually caught onto the second part of the clue and he said it's got to be opera.
And so then we thought La Scala and then the name just popped into my head.
So, those are about the only two names I know of opera.
All right.
Well, shout-out to Dena's husband for helping.
Have you been playing the puzzle a long time?
We've been listening on the radio for 10 years and only really just recently started submitting answers.
All right.
Well, all those people who've been playing for years and years will be a little envious of you, but...
I'm sorry.
...that's the way it goes - randomly selected.
So, what do you do for a living in Harrison?
I actually live out Agate Fossil Beds National Monument south of Harrison.
And I am an architectural historian for the National Park Service.
So, you must live in a beautiful part of the country.
It's lovely and we actually finally got spring a couple of weeks ago and so it's even more lovely.
Dina, do you have a question for Will Shortz?
Unidentified Man #3: Oh, good.
MR.
ADEBAYO: Well let's be real.
Our own political shenanigans are a side show in terms of world politics.
It's all right for domestic consumption whether Prime Minister Gordon Brown is going to survive or not.
Most people think he won't survive.
He's been pretty much a lame duck prime minister for most British people for the last year or so since the economy turned down.
But of course, we know that in America, it's not just a question of Americans going to the poll to nominate a president of the United States.
In effect, it's the president of the world, isn't it?
It's the most powerful job on the planet, and whoever has the keys to Pennsylvania Avenue is going to dominate the world politics for the last - for the next four years or so.
As we saw yesterday with the intervention of George Bush into the fortunes of Freddy Mac and Fannie Mae.
We know that an intervention from an American president can pretty much affect our economy over here.
And until, as I say, Sarah Palin was unveiled, we thought it was a one-horse race.
You wouldn't have even known that John McCain was running, or at least not seriously running.
When he came over to visit world leaders, there wasn't that much attention.
He's not the most attractive person for our television broadcasters or newspapers, and pretty much his speech was dry.
And it represented the old school.
Newspapers, the media, wants to move on, and Sarah Palin and Barack Obama were evidence of that moving forward.
All right.
Kathy, what about you?
You're in Jamaica, and how have people processed it on the ground, as well as you at Radio Jamaica?
It has been overwhelming.
I think ever since Barack Obama entered the race officially, it has taken Jamaica by storm.
The only thing that I think has surpassed it in recent weeks is Jamaica's performance at the Beijing Olympics.

And it is not - although, yes, most Jamaicans know that they don't have a vote by any chance, it's not unusual to hear people on the streets having vigorous conversations about who will be the next president of the United States.
And most Jamaicans, as is the case, I guess, most people in the Caribbean, they're pro-Democrat.
And it's so ironic, when the Republicans had their convention, the average person, and even in a news center such as the one here at Radio Jamaica, it was just a big turnoff for everyone.
Why are we bothering to watch this, because they already assumed that Obama will be the next president of the United States.
So it's being watched very closely by persons from all walks of life across the island.
What do you think of the U.S.
role and responsibility in dealing with Jamaica?
I mean, what do Jamaicans look for from the United States, specifically in inter-country relations?
Well, the U.S.
has always had a major role to play in Jamaica, especially as it relates to our economy.
Tourism is what drives Jamaica's economy, and most of our visitors, at least 85 percent if not more, come to Jamaica from the United States.
So that's one big factor.
Another factor is that a significant number of Jamaicans now live in the United States, and that's where remittances come into play.
The U.S.
is also seen as a country to which, for instance, our dollar is pegged to the U.S.
currency, and in knowing that the U.S.
is just in our backyard, so to speak, is very important in all aspects of Jamaica's life.
Be it related to our economy, even to our politics.
So it's a key factor.
Dotun, we saw some very different rhetoric during the two conventions.
During the Democratic convention, from various speakers, there was a lot of talk of restoring America's relationship with other nations.
During the Republican convention, it was more focused on the need for strong national security, and somewhat more unilateralist, as it has been with the Bush administration.
Not that it was absolutely in lockstep, but there was more of a focus on the U.S.
defending itself, including through, what's being called, you know, energy independence.
How are you picking up on those messages from the two campaigns?
Clearly, the Republican campaign, which we covered at the BBC throughout - I was up for that coverage throughout the night, they were - both Democratic, and the Republican.

The Republican campaign came across to most people here, and I could tell you from the text messages that we had from listeners as well, as very jingoistic and, you know, at times almost unbelievable to a British audience that you could still, in 2008, run a campaign which is based very much on the background chanting of USA, USA, USA.
For us that would seem unseemly.
You know, we're very British, and we try to focus on our role in a global sense.
It would seem very jingoistic to us, and for a Prime Minister to have that kind of background chant in Britain, I think that would be very difficult.
It would be a turnoff.

Having said that, I think what's happened now is that, from our point of view, that the race has become, and probably from American points of views as far as we can see it, has become about personality rather than issues, as such.
I mean, Kathy there in Jamaica will know that there's been a plethora of reggae songs about Obama, but my favorite is one by Coco T, which simply just says, Obama, Obama, on and on.
(Soundbite of laughter)
